sections.title: Integrable Equations and Recursion Operators in Planar Klein Geometries
sections.abstract:
Integrable equations with infinite hierarchies of
symmetries are shown to arise in the context of the evolution of
invariants of planar curves under geometric curve flows.  A
candidate for a recursion operator for these integrable equations
arises naturally within the context of the computation of these
evolution equations.  The techniques of moving frames and the
invariant variational bicomplex are used.
sections.author: Joe Benson
sections.keywords: Integrable equations, Klein geometry, moving frames, motion of plane curves, recursion operators, variational bicomplex
sections.introduction:
\label{introduction}
In \cite{hasimoto1972}, Hasimoto showed that the evolution of a thin
vortex filament  in an inviscid, incompressible fluid is
transformable to the cubic nonlinear Schr\"odinger equation, which
is known to have many of the properties now generally associated to
so-called completely integrable equations, i.e.\ evolution equations
possessing soliton solutions, bihamiltonian structures, solution by
inverse-scattering, auto-B\"acklund transformations, recursion
operators, and infinite hierarchies of generalized symmetries and
conservation laws.  In \cite{lamb1977}, Lamb showed that the motion
of helical space curves were related to the sine-Gordon and Hirota
equations, which can be related to the nonlinear Sch\"odinger and
modified Korteweg--deVries equations, respectively.  What followed
was a proliferation of papers investigating the relationship between
geometric, arc-length preserving (non-stretching) flows and
integrable equations, \cite{GoldsteinPetrich1991,
LangerPerline1998}, including studies into associated Poisson
structures \cite{BeffaOlver2010}, and recursion operators
\cite{Langer1999Recursion}.


  Notably, in \cite{ChouQu2,ChouQu1}, Chou and Qu produced
  a detailed investigation into the relationship between arc-length preserving planar curve flows in
   various Klein geometries and integrable equations describing the evolution of minimal order differential invariants.
    The KdV, mKdV, Burgers', and Sawada--Kotera \cite{SawadaKotera1974} equations, among others naturally arise in this fashion.
     Some of these relationships provide geometric explanations of the Miura transformation, relating the KdV and mKdV equations,
     and the Hopf--Cole transformation relating Burgers' equation with the heat equation.



In \cite{ISF}, Olver uses the techniques of the equivariant method
of moving frames \cite{MC1,MC2}  and the invariant variational
bicomplex \cite{IVB} to investigate invariant submanifold flows and
consequent evolutions of differential invariants.  The advantages of
using this framework are the algorithmic nature of the
constructions, and the ``invariant calculus" which allows for all
relevant computations to be done symbolically, i.e.~ the local
coordinate representation of all invariant functions, forms, and
operators are not needed.  Rather than work with potentially
complicated group actions, and their even more complicated
prolongations, an infinitesimal approach is taken.  The
infinitesimal generators of the group action are combined with the
powerful recurrence formula, \cite{IVB}, which in the case of
curves, allows for a systematic production of the
\emph{characteristic operator}, an integro-differential operator
which determines the evolution of differential invariants under
(group invariant) arc-length preserving flows.

It was observed that in many instances, the characteristic operator
turned out   be the recursion operator for certain integrable
equations.  Recursion operators generate infinite hierarchies of
symmetries, and the existence of one implies integrability of the
associated equation.  The appearance of recursion operators
naturally arising within the bicomplex framework motivated a return
to the results of Chou and Qu.

In the following work, using the techniques developed in \cite{ISF},
we discover integrable evolution equations that govern the flow of
minimal order invariants of planar curves for different Lie group
actions on the plane.  In Section \ref{MFandIF}, we define moving
frames and describe invariant flows. In Section \ref{results}, we go
through the catalog of group actions on the plane, finding
integrable equations describing the evolution of group curvatures.
The characteristic operators are given, and their relationship to
the recursion operators are demonstrated when applicable.  In
Section \ref{discussion}, we pull together a few of the patterns
that arise in the computations, as well as discuss a some of the
implications and possible explanations.
main_part:
\label{MFandIF} Let $G$ be a Lie group acting on a manifold $M$.  A
\emph{moving frame}  is an equivariant map from the manifold back to
the group:
\[\rho:M\to G,\qquad \rho(g\cdot z)=\rho(z) g^{-1},\qquad g\in G, z\in M.\]
The construction of a moving frame relies on the choice of a cross-section, $\mathcal{K}$, to the group orbits.  Geometrically, the moving frame maps a point $z\in M$ to the unique group element that sends it to the cross-section, see Figure \ref{mf}.
\begin{figure}[h]
\begin{center}
\begin{tikzpicture}[scale=1]
\draw[thick,->] (0,0) ..controls (2,.25) and (2.5,.5) .. (3.5, 1)
    node[pos=.8,below right] {orbits};
\draw[thick,->] (0,.5) .. controls (2,.75) and (2.5,1) .. (3.5, 1.5);
\draw[thick,->] (0,1) .. controls (2,1.25) and (2.5,1.5) .. (3.5, 2);
\draw (1,-.25) node[right] {$\mathcal{K}$} -- (1,2);
\fill (1,1.15) circle (1.75pt);
\fill (2.5, 1.55) circle (1.75pt) node[below] {$z$};
\draw[->] (2.3, 1.55) ..controls (1.4,1.6 ) .. (1.1,1.25)
    node[pos=.2,above] {$\rho(z)$}
    node[pos=1.1,above left] {$\rho(z)\cdot z$};
\end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}
\caption{\emph{Construction of a moving frame}}
\label{mf}
\end{figure}
With a moving frame in hand, one can invariantize geometric objects
such  as differential functions and forms.  For example, the
invariantization of a differential function $F(z)$ is the invariant
function $\iota(F)(z)=F(\rho(z)\cdot z)$.  This indeed satisfies the
criterion of invariance: $\iota(F)(g\cdot z)=\iota(F)(z)$.
Geometrically, $\iota(F)(z)$ is the unique function that is constant
on orbits and agrees with $F(z)$ on the cross-section.  In practice,
the group action is prolonged to act on the jets of submanifolds.
The cross-section is then taken on jet space, and the
invariantization process leads to differential invariants.
Typically, moving frames are constructed via a normalization
process, whereby the cross-section is taken to be constant
coordinate values.

Equipped with a moving frame and the process of invariantization, we
are now able to study  curvature evolution under invariant flows.
Since the results below are for curves in the plane, we will
restrict the presentation to these instances, however the methods
used can be generalized.

An invariant curve flow is a $G$-invariant evolutionary partial
differential equation $\pd{C}{t}=\Phi[C]$ governing the motion of a
planar curve $C\subset \RR^2 (\text{or } \CC^2)$.  Here, that $G$ is
a symmetry group means that if $C(t)$ is a solution and $g\in G$ is
a fixed group transformation, then $\widetilde{C}(t)=g\cdot C(t)$ is
another solution.  The invariant flow can be represented by a
section of the bundle $T\RR^2\to C$, written in coordinates by
$\VV=\VV|_C=I\ttt+J\nn$ where $\ttt$ and $\nn$ are the group
invariant tangential and normal directions, respectively, and $I$
and $J$ are differential invariants.  The tangential component, $I$,
does not affect the extrinsic geometry of the flow, but only its
internal parameterizations.  Hence, the normal component, $J$, fully
determines the image of $C(t)$ under the flow.

The vortex filament flow mentioned in  the introduction is an
example of an arc-length preserving flow.  We are interested in
flows that preserve a group invariant parameter, for this allows
arc-length and time differentiation to commute:
$[\pd{}{s},\pd{}{t}]=0$.  It turns out that in order to preserve the
parameterization, the tangential coefficient $I$ must depend in a
particular way on the normal coefficient $J$.  It is not uncommon
that in arc-length preserving flows, the tangential coefficient may
be nonlocal.  However, we can accept this reality and commit our
focus to the normal coefficient $J$.

\begin{example}
Let $G=SE(2)$ be the Euclidean group acting by rigid motions on  the
plane, and let $\ttt$ and $\nn$ be the unit tangent and normal
vectors to a smooth curve in the plane.  The flow
$\VV=I\ttt+J\nn=\frac12\kap^2\ttt+\kap_s\nn$ preserves the Euclidean
arc-length, where $\kap$ is the Euclidean curvature, and
differentiation is with respect to Euclidean arc-length,
$\kap_s=\pd{}{s}\kap=\D\kap$.  Alternatively, with normal component
$J=\kap$, the associated arc-length preserving flow has the form
$$\VV=(\D^{-1}\kap^2)\;\ttt+\kap\nn=\left(\int\kap^2\;ds\right)\ttt+\kap\nn.$$
\end{example}
Given an arbitrary group action, one can define  the group invariant
parameter, $s$, with which to parametrize the curve.  A choice is
made on a lowest order differential invariant, which will always be
denoted by $\kap$ below.  Indeed, with the moving frame, $\kap$ is
always taken to be the invariantization of the first non-normalized
jet coordinate.  The evolution of this invariant under the flow is
determined by the \emph{characteristic operator}, an
integro-differential operator associated to $\kap$ and constructed
through the choice of $\kap$ and $s$.  The characteristic operator
will always be denoted by $\PP$ below.  To determine the evolution
of $\kap$, we apply the characteristic operator to the normal
component of the flow, $J$.

\begin{example}
The characteristic operator for the Euclidean curvature is
$\PP=\D^2+\kap^2+\kap_s\D^{-1}\cdot\kap.$   Here (and below)
$\D=\pd{}{s}$ is differentiation with respect to arc-length (the
group invariant parameter).  The $\D^{-1}$ term can be treated as a
formal inverse to $\D$.  For the flow above, with normal component
$J=\kap_s$, the evolution of $\kap$ is
$$\kap_t=\PP(\kap_s)=(\D^2+\kap^2+\kap_s\D^{-1}\cdot\kap)(\kap_s)=\kap_{sss}+\frac32\kap^2\kap_s,$$
which is the mKdV equation.
\end{example}\begin{remark}
The construction of the characteristic operator is a fairly
straightforward process,  but requires the use of the invariant
variational bicomplex.  Discussion of this important and interesting
tool would take us too far from our goal of describing integrable
equations and their recursion operators arising in the context of
invariant flows.  See \cite{VB, IVB} for information on the
variational bicomplex, and \cite{ISF} for details on how it is used
in the construction of invariant flows and the characteristic
operator.
\end{remark}%%%%%%% Section 3    %%%%%%%

Table \ref{list} reproduces the tables found in \cite{olverpurple},
pages 472-473.  The table gives a complete classification of Lie
algebras of vector fields on $\CC^2$, first compiled by Sophus Lie
himself. The vector fields in the first category are transitive and
imprimitive.  Those in the second category are transitive and
primitive, and those in the third are intransitive.  An imprimitive
action is one that admits an invariant foliation of the manifold.
For example, case 1.7 admits two invariant foliations, by horizontal
and vertical lines.  The local action induced by these generators
preserve this foliation, i.e. horizontal (vertical) lines are mapped
to horizontal (vertical) lines.

 We employ the following notation for the partial derivatives in the $x$ and $u$
  directions:  $p:=\pd{}{x}$ and $q:=\pd{}{u}$.  In cases 1.5, 1.6, 3.1 and 3.2, the functions
    $ \eta_1(x),\ldots,\eta_k(x)$ satisfy a $k$th order constant coefficient
    homogeneous linear ordinary differential equation.  For cases 1.5--1.11, 3.1 and 3.2, we require $k\geq1$.
     The situations where $k=0$ are equivalent to other cases already listed.
      The numbering above will be referenced in the following analysis, however it is merely a convenience,
      and no claim is made on the benefits of this particular ordering.

In the tables below, the following data is given: the reference
number from Table \ref{list} and Lie algebra structure, the
cross-section used in the computations, the definition of $\kap$,
the characteristic operator, $\PP$, the evolution $\PP(J)$, the
identification of the evolution equation when applicable, and the
relationship between the associated recursion operator and $\PP$.

The notation for the cross-section  is
$\{x^0,u^0,u_x^0,u^0_{xx},\ldots, u^0_n\}$, where the entries are
the cross-section constants, i.e. $u_k=u_k^0$.  For example
$\{0,1,0\}$ implies the cross-section $x=0, u=1, u_x=0$.  In all
cases, coordinate cross-sections were used.  The moving frame
algorithm allows for more complicated cross-sections, and there is a
technique for writing the invariants given by one cross-section in
terms of the invariants given by another.  Hence, we strive for
computational simplicity in using only coordinate cross-sections.
In general,  0 and 1 are used for cross-sectional coordinates,
however in some instances, values other than 1 are used.

The integrable equations that arise in  the following computations
are included in Table \ref{eqn} below for reference.  In each of the
instances below, $\kap_t=\R(\kap_s)$.  In the following
computations, higher order members of the hierarchy appear.  For

\[\kap_t=\R^2(\kap_s)=(\D^2+2\kap+\kap_s\D^{-1})(\kap_{sss}+3\kap\kap_s)=\kap_{sssss}+5\kap\kap_{sss}+10\kap_s\kap_{ss}+\frac{15}{2}\kap^2\kap_s,\]
the second member in the KdV hierarchy.

The cases presented in Table \ref{sl(2)} represent the  three
inequivalent actions of $\mathfrak{sl}(2)$ as well as the six
dimensional action of $\mathfrak{sl}(2)\oplus\mathfrak{sl}(2)$.
Note that the two transitive cases (1.1 and 1.2) produce the
integrable KdV and mKdV equations where $\PP$ is the associated
recursion operator.  The third case (3.3) also produces the KdV
equation with normal component $J=\kap$, however the KdV recursion
operator is given by $\R_{\text{KdV}}=\PP\D^{-1}$.  This represents
the first of many instances where $J=\kap$ produces an integrable
equation in which the associated recursion operator $\R$ is written
$\R=\PP\D^{-1}$.

%It is also worth mentioning that there is a connection between these three inequivalent actions, as noted in \cite{chazy}.  If we write case 1.1 using $(y,v)$ coordinates, then the transformation defined by%\[y=x,\qquad v=1/u_x\]%transforms the prolonged vector fields of case 3.3 to case 1.1.  Writing case 1.2 in $(z,w)$ coordinates, we have the transformation%\[z=y,\qquad w=v_y/2v\]%which transforms the prolonged vector fields of case 1.1 to case 1.2.  It is interesting to note that the extra $\D^{-1}$ term appearing as the obstruction to $\PP_{3.3}$ being a recursion operator arises from this change of coordinates taking case 3.3 to case 1.1.  Similarly, the mKdV equation from case 1.2 transforms to an integrable equation written in terms of invariants from the action of case 1.1, which itself is transformable back to the mKdV equation, from which we can find the KdV equation via the Miura transformation.  Complete details of these transformations would take us too far astray, but merit further investigation.
The last entry in Table \ref{sl(2)} demonstrates the appearance of the KdV equation within the six-dimensional action of $\mathfrak{sl}(2)\oplus\mathfrak{sl}(2)$.  Note that with $J=1$, we find the KdV equation with a translational term, but with $J=\kap$, we find a combination of the KdV equation and the second member of its hierarchy.  The operator $\PP$ is not the associated recursion operator, but similar to case 3.3,  $\hat{\R}=\PP\D^{-1}$ can be viewed as a fourth order recursion operator for the KdV equation.  More precisely, the KdV hierarchy is usually generated by the second order recursion operator $\R_{\text{KdV}}=\D^2+2\kap+\kap_s\D^{-1}$, hence we can write $\hat{\R}=\R_{\text{KdV}}^2-5\R_{\text{KdV}}+6=\PP\D^{-1}$.

Table \ref{1.10} shows results of the action of  case 1.10 for $k=1,
2, 3$ and 4.  We see that when $k=1$ and $k=3$, we have $J=\kap$
producing the KdV equation and the recursion operator appears as
$\R=\PP\D^{-1}$ in each case.  In the latter case we again find the
second member of the KdV hierarchy.

When $k=2$, we find the Sawada--Kotera equation, but $\PP$ is not
the recursion operator in this case.  The recursion operator is
given as $\R_{\text{SW}}=\PP(\D^2+\f3\kap+\f3\kap_s\D^{-1}),$ see
\cite{ChouQu1}.  The Sawada--Kotera equation, like most of the
integrable evolution equations we encounter, start with the ``seed''
symmetry $\kap_s$.  In most cases, we apply the associated recursion
operator to $\kap_s$ to produce our integrable equation.  The
Sawada--Kotera equation is different in that we apply $\PP$ to
$\kap_s$ to produce the equation, yet $\PP$ is not the recursion
operator.  In fact, the next member of the hierarchy is found by
applying $\R_{\text{SW}}$ to $\kap_s$ to produce a 7th order
equation.  Hence, there are two sequences in the Sawada--Kotera
hierarchy.  They can be written
$\kap_t=\R_{\text{SW}}^{n-1}\PP(\kap_s)$, and
$\kap_t=\R_{\text{SW}}^n(\kap_s),\qquad n=1,2,\ldots.$ Note the
orders of the first sequence are $5, 11, 17,\ldots$ and the orders
of the second sequence are $7, 13, 19, \ldots$.  When $k=4$, we
recover the 7th order Sawada--Kotera equation.  However, the
characteristic operator $\PP$ is not the associated recursion
operator.  It is unclear if and how the recursion operator for the
Sawada--Kotera equation relates to $\PP$ in this instance.

In Table \ref{gl2}, we have the actions of cases 1.3 and 1.11 $k=1$,
which have the Lie algebra structure  of $\mathfrak{gl}(2)$ and
$\mathfrak{gl}(2)\ltimes\CC$, respectively.  Looking first at case
1.3 we see that the chosen cross-section and $J$ coefficient produce
a KdV-mKdV hybrid equation, which has been referred to as the
Gardner equation in the literature, \cite{Debnath2005}.  The Gardner
equation arises via a generalization of the Miura transform relating
solutions of the mKdV equation to solutions of the KdV equation.
Indeed, if $v$ satisfies the mKdV equation, then $u=v^2+v_x$
satisfies the KdV equation.  The generalization, referred to as the
Gardner transformation in \cite{Debnath2005}, uses
$v=\frac12\varepsilon^{-1}+\varepsilon w$ instead of just $v$.  The
Miura transform thus becomes $u=\f4\varepsilon^{-2}+w+\varepsilon
w_x+\varepsilon^2 w^2$. The constant can be absorbed into the
solution for $u$, and so we have $u=w+\varepsilon w_x+\varepsilon^2
w^2$. This is the Gardner transformation. Solutions $w$ of the
Gardner equation determine solutions of the KdV equation through
this transformation.  Furthermore, the Gardner equation is
integrable.

Looking back at Table \ref{gl2}, the recursion operator for the
Gardner  equation found in case 1.3 is given by $\R_G=\PP\D^{-1}$.
We remark here that using the alternate cross-section
$\{0,1,0,1/2\}$, the algorithm produces the mKdV equation:
$\kap_t=\PP(\kap)=\kap_{sss}-\fr32\kap^2\kap_s-2\kap_s$ where
similarly, $\R_{mKdV}=\PP\D^{-1}$.

Case 1.7 is presented in Table \ref{1.7}.  Notice that this case
contains an  arbitrary parameter $\al$.  If $\al\neq1$, the general
formula for $\PP$ is given, however this will not produce integrable
equations for arbitrary $\al$.  For the particular values of $\al$
listed though, we do find some of the equations we are searching
for.  When $\al=0$, we find Burgers' equation.  The corresponding
recursion operator is $\R_B=\PP\D^{-1}$.  When $\al=-1$, we find the
mKdV equation with the corresponding recursion operator matching
exactly, $\R_{mKdV}=\PP$.

 When $\al=1/2$ or 2 we find the second member of the Burgers' hierarchy.   In this instance, the recursion operator for Burgers' equation is
 $\R_B=\D+\kap+\kap_s\D^{-1}$.
 We focus on the $\al=2$ case to  simplify the presentation, omitting the $\pm$'s.  Hence, $\PP(\kap)=\R_B^2(\kap_s)$.  However, the factorization of $\PP$ is as follows:
 \[\PP=\D^2+3\kap\D+\kap_s+2\kap^2+2\kap_s\D^{-1}\cdot\kap=(\D+\kap+\kap_s\D^{-1})(\D+2\kap)=\R_B(\D+2\kap).\]
So $\PP=\R_B(\D+2\kap)$.  Note that the operator $\D+2\kap$ produces the right-hand side of Burgers' equation when applied to $\kap_s$, but is not a recursion operator:
\[(\D+2\kap)(\kap_s)=\kap_{ss}+2\kap\kap_s=(\D+\kap+\kap_s\D^{-1})(\kap_s).\]
In the instance where $\al=1$, we have that $u_x$ is invariant, and cannot be used in the construction of a coordinate cross-section.  The cross-section used is $x=u=0, u_{xx}=1$, and the curvature is taken to be $\kap=\iota(u_{xxx})$.  With $J=\kap$, we have the second equation in Burgers' hierarchy and another instance of $\R_B=\PP\D^{-1}$.

 Here we make a few further observations about some of the patterns that arise.   First, we see from Table \ref{summary table} that instances in which the characteristic operator is the same as an associated recursion operator ($\R=\PP$) is in fact not entirely common.  The dimension of the group plays some role here.  For instance, the dimension of Case 1.1 is 3, so the lowest order invariant has order 2.  The characteristic operator for this invariant will be a second order differential operator, which matches the order of the recursion operator for the KdV equation. Alternatively, we see that the dimension of the Lie algebra coincides with the order of the integrable equation. This pattern holds for the first 4 cases listed.  Case 3.1 is a primitive action, written locally in terms of evolutionary vector fields, and thus $x$ is an invariant.  In this case, $\kap=\iota(u_x)$, which produces a first order differential operator which matches the recursion operator of the heat equation.  It should also be mentioned that $J=\kap_s$ is the ``seed" symmetry for each of the KdV, mKdV and heat equations.

 Contrast this dimensional analysis to the much more common situation in the second part of
 Table \ref{summary table}, where $\R=\PP\D^{-1}$.  Here, the order of  the characteristic operator is one more  than the order of the recursion operators of the equations we find.  Attaching a $\D^{-1}$ in front of these characteristic operators produces the desired recursion operators in all these situations.  Of course, we recognize the reoccurring pattern:
 $\kap_t=\PP(\kap)=\PP\D^{-1}\D(\kap)=\PP\D^{-1}(\kap_s)$.
 In all instances listed in the second part of Table \ref{summary table}, we find the relationship that $\R=\PP\D^{-1}$.  Again, we can alternatively see that the dimension of the Lie algebra is one more than the order of the integrable equation.

The Sawada--Kotera equation makes a few appearances on the list,
which are singled out.  Since the hierarchy for this equation is
non-standard, the relationship between the recursion operator and
the characteristic operator doesn't fit into the patterns already
demonstrated.  Furthermore, the third of the Sawada--Kotera
instances shown gives the 7th order equation in the hierarchy, and
there's no clear relationship between the characteristic operator
and the associated recursion operator.

The last section in Table \ref{summary table} lists a few of the
cases  which don't seem to fall into an obvious pattern.  Case 1.7
gives the 3rd order Burgers' equation, but $\PP$ decomposes as the
first order Burgers' recursion operator with an extra factor.  Case
1.8 doesn't give an integrable equation, but the characteristic
operator similarly decomposes as Burgers' first order recursion
operator with an extra factor.  Case 1.11 gives the fifth order mKdV
equation, but $J=\kap_s-\fr12\kap^2$ is different than all other $J$
choices.  Further, the relationship between the characteristic
operator and the recursion operator is still unclear.

Though space precluded discussion of the variational bicomplex, the
role of this  structure in arriving at the above computations should
not be discounted.  Indeed, in a sense, the characteristic operator
can be shown to be built precisely from the exterior derivative
applied to $\kap$.
